  • Description: SequenceEvent: shipment taken out of system flow due to external carton wet ripped torn open upon inspection of inner contents 6 x 2.5 liter plastic bottles of hydrochloric acid acs one 2.5 liter plastic bottle had a loose cap allowing .50 liters to release no slotted partitions bags or absorbent was found. facility procedures for damaged hazardous materials followed contents contained and awaiting disposition. DescribePack: one 2.5 liter plastic bottle had a loose cap allowing .50 liters to release DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: leaking package was placed in a hazmat bag lined tote

item.title: Report X-2024020959
item.description:
Report X-2024020959

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-27T18:13:01+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-02-06
  • City: KEASBEY
  • State: NJ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: 1. X-2024020959 SequenceEvent: Package arrived at the Hazmat cage during the Day Sort with signs of external damage due to internal leakage. Upon inspection of the package and its contents one of the four bottles was found without a cap. The remaining contents were placed in a salvage drum awaiting disposition. DescribePack: The package failure was due to a missing cap. Approximately 1/16 of the contents was leaked out of the package. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: The package was immediately inspected and placed into a lined salvage drum to prevent any further leakage or damages. 2. X-2024020963 SequenceEvent: DURING THE OVERNIGHT SORT THE PACKAGE ARRIVED AT THE HAZMAT CAGE SHOWING OBVIOUS SIGNS OF INTERNAL LEAKAGE. UPON INSPECTION ONE BOTTLE (PARTB) OF RAPICIDE WAS FOUND 1/2 WAY LEAKED OUT. THE REMAINING CONTENTS WERE PLACED IN A SALVAGE DRUM TO BE RETURN TO SHIPPER UNLESS OTHERWISE. DescribePack: FAILURE OF RAPICIDE CAUSED FROM THE PACKAGE BEING DROPPED OR MISHANDLED. DurationRel: 24 and MitigateEffect: CONTENTS WERE PLACED IN A LINED SALVAGE DRUM TO AWAIT DISPOSITION.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: Pkg was loaded and scanned as delivered, pkg was picked up and leak was noticed. Given to QA when the driver arrived back to the station. QA immediately transported the damage hazmat in a lined hazardous tote to the hazmat processing area. DescribePack: Loose closure at top of bottle. DurationRel: 2 and MitigateEffect: The truck the pkg was loaded on was properly cleaned of spilled material. Driver was informed on how to deal with damaged hazardous material ad how to safely transport them to the station.

item.title: Report X-2024020928
item.description:
Report X-2024020928

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-27T18:13:01+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-02-05
  • City: MISSOURI CITY
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package was repacked by an unauthorized personnel. It was loaded onto a truck leaking with the orientation arrows not facing upwards and the driver did not notice till the end of his route. He returned the package back to station as needing an inspection and it was discovered during VSA. Once inspected, the truck and area was temporarily evacuated. The hazardous material was transported to the hazardous processing area in a lined hazardous tote. DescribePack: 4 bottles had either a cracked or loose closure. DurationRel: 2 and MitigateEffect: QA team members were told the correct procedures of handling a damage hazmat so no further damage can occur. The driver was informed of the actions he should take when a hazardous material is leaking on their truck.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: DURING THE UNLOAD THE MANAGER NOTICED THE PACKAGE WAS WET AND IMMEDIATELY TOOK THE PACKAGE OVER TO THE HAZMAT CAGE TO SECURE IT AND VENTILATE IT PROPERLY. I THEN REPACKED IT IN A SMALL WHITE SALVAGE DRUM IN A TIMELY AND SAFE MANNER. DescribePack: APPROXIMATELY 1/2 CUP LEAKED FROM TWO OF THE FOUR BOTTLES INSIDE THE PACKAGE. A TOTAL OF 1 CUP OF DISINFECTANT LEAKED OUT DUE TO LOOSE CAPS. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: IMMEDIATELY TAKING THE PACKAGE OVER TO THE HAZMAT CAGE TO SECURE IT AND VENTILATE IT PROPERLY AND THEN HAVING ME REPACK IT INTO A WHITE SALVAGE DRUM IN A TIMELY AND SAFE MANNER.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: First noticed by a package handler on the conveyor belt due to the smell. QA was called and removed package and put in bag lined red hazmit bin. There was leakage on the belt. Leakage was tested and cleaned up with absorbent pads. DescribePack: The bottles of Part B have a small hole in the cap. The safety seal on one of the bottles was punctured or burst and the liquid was able to leak out of the hole in the cap. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: The package was put in a plastic lined red hazmat bin and the residue on the belt was tested as negative.

item.title: Report X-2024020961
item.description:
Report X-2024020961

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-27T18:13:01+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-02-06
  • City: ALBUQUERQUE
  • State: NM
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package was found on the van in wet/crushed condition. Upon further inspection, found 4 of 8 contents to have had loose caps which caused leakage. Remaining 4 items were stained with leakage from surrounding contents. All contents were placed into a cleanup bin to be taken to a QA cage for further inspection. The spillage on the van was neutralized by Amphomag Spill Neutralizer and was swept into a cleanup bin. DescribePack: 4 of 8 inner packaging bottles had loose caps which caused leakage throughout packaging. DurationRel: 3 and MitigateEffect: As soon as spillage was known, cleanup and neutralization processes were immediately performed to prevent further leakage.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: BOX LEFT OUTSIDE OF HWPA, BAGGED, IN A RED TOTE. DescribePack: ORIGINAL BOX NOT PRESENT. BOTTLES REPACKED IN CARDBOARD BOX. DurationRel: 2 and MitigateEffect: DAMAGED BOTTLES WERE BAGGED IN BLUE HAZMAT BAGS, ZIP TIED AND KNOTTED. ALL PACKAGING AND DAMAGES WERE PLACED IN A LINED 20 GALLON SALVAGE DRUM.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On February 14, 2024, four (4) one-gallon bottles of UN3266 were crushed during transit and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Hull's Environmental Services (HES) to remediate the impacted site. HES personnel deployed absorbent pads to the UN3266-impacted dock floor. Crews then restacked and wrapped all undamaged freight for future use. All spent absorbents and damaged product were collected and containerized into two (2) 55-gallon drums which were staged onsite for future disposal.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XPB experienced a UN1307 Unisol Liquid Red B-75 release from a 350-gallon metal tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 2 cups of product released to a 1’ x 1’ area of the tote body. The crew confirmed the tote lid appear to be damaged by freight falling onto the lid. All free liquid was wiped off the damaged tote with absorbent pads and placed into a 55-gallon metal drum. The tote was staged onsite pending a new lid from the shipper. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XSW experienced a UN3265 Dequest 2000 release from a 55-gallon poly drum. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 30-gallons of product released to a 5’ x 5’ area of the trailer floor and a 20’ x 8’ area of the concrete lot below due to a forklift puncture. Absorbents and soda ash were deployed to neutralize and clean the impacted areas. The impacted absorbents were then collected into (2) 55-gallon poly drums. The damaged drum of material was placed into an 85-gallon poly overpack. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: On February 14, 2024, one (1) 5-gallon jerrican of hydrogen peroxide was damaged in a load shift and released approximately 5-gallons of product to the trailer interior. Crews deployed granular absorbent to the trailer floor and dock surface. FCE personnel worked the granular absorbents in with hand tools, utilizing a degreasing agent with absorbent wipes to collect any residual product. All hydrogen peroxide impacted material was collected and containerized in two (2) 55-gallon drums and RLC personnel took possession of the waste.

THE DANGEROUS GOODS SHIPMENT HAD PREVIOUSLY PASSED AN ACCEPTANCE AUDIT AT THE ORIGIN FACILITY. UPON INSPECTION OF THE CONTENTS DISCOVERED (1) 6.7 OUNCE BOTTLE OF RITUAL OF MEHR NOURISHING SHOWER OIL LEAKING FROM THE CLOSURE. THE BLACK PUSH CAP WAS OPEN WHEN THEY INSPECTED THE PACKAGE WHICH CAUSED APPROXIMATELY 5 OUNCES TO LEAK TO THE EXTERIOR OF THE BOX. THE SECOND LEAKER WAS (1) 0.6 OUNCE THE RITUAL OF KARMA HAIR AND BODY MIST. THIS LEAKED APPROXIMATELY 0.3 OUNCES. THE CLEAR PLASTIC COVER FOR THE SPRAY NOZZLE WAS NOT ON WHEN THEY OPENED THE BOX. THE PACKAGE WAS SHIPPED FROM THE NETHERLANDS GOING TO THE USA USING UPS ACCOUNT NUMBER B567J0, ARVATO BENELUX BV, BREM 1, HEIJEN NETHERLANDS 6598MH.

  • City: CLEVELAND
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 02/01/2024, at 0900 hours, personnel in the CSXT Collinwood Yard discovered MJEX 73527, a loaded tank car of Methyl Isobutyl Carbinol, leaking from the manway area. The car was isolated and The Shipper, Altivia, was notified via CHEMTREC (Report 2024-0201-00063). EnviroServe, a CSXT emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found the product leaking from the liquid line valve mounting flange as a result of the mounting flange bolts being less than tool tight. Contractor personnel tightened the flange bolts to stop the release. The issue identified and corrective action were communicated to the shipper’s representative (Timothy Albert, 740-533-5200). The car was held out of transportation pending further repair/qualification by a certified mobile repair unit or One Time Movement Approval (OTMA) from FRA.

  • Description: On February 15, 2024, one (1) 1-gallon bottle of UN3266 was damaged and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the trailer floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. Crews deployed a neutralizing agent to the impacted area. Once neutralized, FCE personnel deployed granular absorbent to the trailer floor and worked them in with hand tools, utilizing a degreasing agent with absorbent wipes to collect any residual product. All UN3266 impacted material was collected and containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum and RLC personnel took possession of the waste

  • City: HONOLULU

  • Description: 1. X-2024021067 FIVE AIR PACKAGES FROM HONOLULU, HAWAII GOING TO KIHEI/WAILEA POST OFFICE IN KIHEI, HI WERE INSPECTED. UPON INSPECTION OF THE CONTENTS DISCOVERED INNER BOXES WITH GROUND LIMITED QUANTITY MARKINGS. THE INNER BOXES CONTAINED VARIOUS FLAMMABLE AEROSOLS. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTERMOST BLACK SHIPPING BAGS TO DECLARE THE FLAMMABLE AEROSOLS. ADDITIONAL TRACKING NUMBERS ARE 1Z7R29940169073863, 1Z7R29940168383244, 1Z7R29940167378252 AND 1Z7R29940167222713. 2. X-2024021068 AN AIR SHIPMENT FROM HONOLULU, HAWAII GOING TO THE HILO POST OFFICE IN HILO, HAWAII WAS INSPECTED. UPON INSPECTION OF THE CONTENTS DISCOVERED TWO INNER FIBERBOARD BOXES WITH ONE BOX MARKED AS GROUND LIMITED QUANTITY. INSPECTION OF INNER BOX CONTENTS REVEALS ONE BIOFREEZE ROLL ON GEL CONTAINING ISOPROPYL ALCOHOL. THE PACKAGE ALSO CONTAINS TWO X 2 OZ CVS MOISTURING HAND SANITIZER GELS. THE ACTIVE INGREDIENT IN THE HAND SANITIZERS IS ETHYL ALCOHOL 70% WHICH WILL MEET THE EXCEPTION 173.150(G). THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTERMOST BLACK SHIPPING BAG TO DECLARE THE ISOPROPYL ALCOHOL.

  • Description: XPO notified ERTS regarding a leaking valve on metal tote containing flammable product. A Contractor was called to evaluate the leak and determine whether or not a tote transfer would be necessary. The Contractor was able to clean-up the spillage and tighten the valve. The tote ceased leaking, therefore, it was determined that a tote transfer would not be necessary. One drum of waste was produced containing impacted absorbent pads. No storm-drains, waterways, or soil were impacted by the release.

  • Description: On February 12, 2024, three (3) 5-gallon pails of ink were damaged due to a load shift and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the trailer floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Graymar Environmental Services (GES) to remediate the impacted site. GES personnel containerized the three (3) 5-gallon pails into one (1) 55-gallon drum. The crew then deployed absorbents to the release and collected and containerized the spent absorbents in one (1) additional 55-gallon drum for disposal.

  • Description: On February 13, 2024, one (1) 5-gallon pail of paint was damaged by a forklift and released approximately five (5) gallons of product to the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. FCE personnel deployed granular absorbents to the paint-impacted dock and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum. The damaged pail was collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum. Both containers were staged onsite for future disposal.

  • Incident Date: 2024-02-05
  • City: PENDLETON
  • State: KY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: CLEAN HARBORS ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Driver was starting his trip for the day and when doing his Pre-Trip noticed liquid on the floor of the trailer and called our emergency response line. Call was received at around 1115et. A team was dispatched and was in rout at 1230et, They arrived on scene at 1330et and started the process of getting information and dawning the appropriate PPE to begin the clean up. They had to remove several containers to get to the drum which was near the middle of a 53ft trailer. They found the drum and noted that it had a small hole in the side that the material was leaking out. The drum was put into a salvage drum and the material was cleaned up using absorbent materials and then disposed of properly. This was completed at approximately 1800et. The containers that had to be removed to gain excess were then reloaded and secured for shipment at 1900et.

  • City: WILMINGTON

  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On February 15, 2024, one (1) 2,100-pound super sack of ammonium nitrate was damaged by a faulty pallet and released approximately seven (7) pounds of product to the loading dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted site. TLE personnel utilized absorbents, hand tools, and a vacuum unit to remediate the ammonium nitrate-impacted loading dock floor. The damaged super sack was patched, wrapped in poly sheeting and taken to be shrink wrapped to continue on to its destination. All waste was collected and containerized into one (1) 15-gallon poly vented drum and staged on site for transport and disposal.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On February 15, 2204, one (1) 330-gallon tote of UN1219 had a faulty cap during transit and released approximately 165-gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted site. Crews deployed granular absorbents to the impacted surface and worked them in with hand tools. A forklift provided by RLC was used to gravity transfer the remaining product from the one (1) damaged 330-gallon tote into one (1) new 330-gallon tote. Absorbent pads and cleaners were used to remove all residual product from the impacted surfaces. All UN1219-impacted materials were collected and containerized into one (1) 5-gallon pail for disposal purposes.

  • Description: A FULLY LABELLED HAZMAT PACKAGE THAT APPEARED TO BE LEAKING FROM A CORNER OF THE BOX WAS DISCOVERED BY A LOADER ON THE PD 2. THE LOADER LEFT THE AREA AND NOTIFIED HIS SUPERVISOR WHO THEN CONTACTED THE DMP. WITHIN 3 MINUTES A DMP RESPONDER ARRIVED DONNING THE APPROPRIATE PPE. USING THE DECISION TREE AND CORRECT RESPONSE SHEET IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE PACKAGE COULD BE SAFELY TRANSPORTED BACK TO THE DMP PROCESSING AREA. UPON FURTHER INSPECTION IT WAS REVEALED THAT THE CAP ON ONE OF THE INNER 2 LITER PLASTIC CONTAINERS WAS LOOSE BY 1/8 OF A TURN AND 1 OUNCE OF LIQUID HAD LEAKED OUT ONTO THE OUTER PACKAGING. THE INNER CONTAINERS WERE INDIVIDUALLY WRAPPED IN PLASTIC BAGS AND THERE WAS NO OTHER PACKING MATERIAL.

Report E-2024020442

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-23T18:13:34+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-02-19
  • City: LYNCHBURG
  • State: VA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: CLI TRANSPORT, LP
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Company Fuel Driver was delivering gasoline at store at 09:03am. Company driver had two hoses connected from the trailer belly valves to the underground fuel storage tank (UST), and was in the process of unloading fuel. Cones were in place to protect the area as well as vehicle lights activated for warnings. A white pickup truck (Super Duty) bearing Maryland registration # 9EC0549, pulling a cement mixer trailer, disregarded the activated lights and orange security cones of our vehicle; and drove over the hose fitting connected to the UST and tore the delivery hose coupler and the lip off the UST, subsequently releasing approximately 20 gallons of gasoline onto the pavement. VA State Police (Trooper J.B. Moore) was notified, arrived at the location of the "hit and run" regarding the pickup truck. Fuel driver captured a photo of the truck license plate that ran over the fitting and hose and provided plate # to Law Enforcement. Material spilled was contained by the fuel driver using absorbent pads, and emptied the remaining fuel in the hose into the UST. No fuel contaminated the ground nor entered into any water systems.

BOTH PACKAGES HAD PREVIOUSLY PASSED ACCEPTANCE AUDITS AT THEIR ORIGIN FACILITIES IN THE NETHERLANDS. UPON INSPECTION OF TRACKING NUMBER 1ZB567J00459689513, ONE X 500 ML BOTTLE OF FLAMMABLE WILD FIG HOME PERFUME SPRAY WAS LEAKING FROM A LOOSE CLOSURE. UPON INSPECTION OF TRACKING NUMBER 1ZB567J00459689282, ONE X 6.7 OZ AEROSOL CAN OF RITUAL OF MEHR FOAMING SHOWER GEL HAD LEAKED FROM THE CLOSURE. THE SECOND PRODUCT LEAKING IN THE BOX WAS ONE X 3.3 OUNCE BOTTLE OF RITUALS OF MEHR DRY OIL FOR THE BODY LEAKING APPROXIMATELY ONE OUNCE FROM A LOOSE CLOSURE. THESE PACKAGES WERE SHIPPED FROM THE NETHERLANDS GOING TO THE USA USING UPS ACCOUNT NUMBER B567J0, ARVATO BENELUX BV, BREM 1, HEIJEN NETHERLANDS 6598MH.

The team then rescued the lid to the drum and cleaned up the material with absorbents and disposed of them in accordance with the regulations.   • City: OKLAHOMA CITY

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Description: On February 10, 2024, one (1) 275-gallon tote of UN1760 was damaged due to unknown causes and released approximately seven (7) gallons of product to the trailer floor, lift gate, wood, and asphalt ground. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Environmental Restoration, LLC (ER) to remediate the impacted site. Crews deployed granular absorbents to the impacted areas and worked them in with hand tools. A hose was utilized to perform a gravity transfer to remove the remaining product from the damaged tote into a new tote provided by ER. The new tote was properly labeled and left on-site for disposal. Crews dismantled the damaged tote and impacted wooden pallet with hand tools for disposal purposes. All spent absorbents, impacted pallet, and tote were collected and containerized into five (5) 55-gallon drums for disposal.

  • Description: On February 12, 2024, twenty-four (24) 12-ounce cans of aerosol paint (UN1263) were punctured by a forklift and released approximately two (2) gallons of product to the cardboard box and trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Hull's Environmental Services (HES) to remediate the impacted site. Crews utilized absorbent pads to collect all freestanding product, and any residual material was removed with a degreasing agent. All spent absorbent pads and impacted cardboard were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum, and the damaged cans were collected and containerized into one (1) additional 55-gallon drum. The drums were properly labeled and possession of the material was taken by R+L for disposal through their bulk waste stream.

item.title: Report X-2024021019
item.description:
Report X-2024021019

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-21T15:11:40+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-02-08
  • City: NORTH SALT LAKE
  • State: UT
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: 1. X-2024021019 SequenceEvent: Package was found with the bottom of the box wet while loading. Upon inspection There are 4 1-gallon bottles inside of the box in a plastic bag, 3 of which looked like they had leaked from the cap. At some point during transit, the package could have been put on its side or upside down, not following the direction of the orientation arrows. No other cracks or holes were found that would result in contents leaking. Package was put in a red hazmat tote and taken to a designated QA area for processing. DescribePack: All bottles still had the caps on them but still resulted in them leaking. No other defects were found. DurationRel: 3 and MitigateEffect: Package was put in a red hazmat tote and taken to a designated QA area for processing. 2. X-2024021026 SequenceEvent: Package was found with the bottom of the box wet while loading. Upon inspection there are 4 1-gallon bottles inside of the box in a plastic bag, 1 of which was leaking from the cap when put upside down or on its side. Package at some point during transit was most likely put on its side resulting in contents leaking. Package was put in a red hazmat tote and taken to a designated QA area for processing. DescribePack: One bottle had a loose cap resulting in it leaking contents when put on its side or upside down. DurationRel: 4 and MitigateEffect: Package was put in a red hazmat tote and taken to a designated QA area for processing.

  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On February 8, 2024, three (3) 5-gallon containers of isopropanol arrived damaged due to unknown causes and released approximately ten (10) gallons of product to the trailer interior and pavement beneath. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted site. TLE personnel utilized hand tools and absorbents to remediate the isopropanol-impacted trailer and concrete. TLE crews collected and containerized all impacted material into two (2) 55-gallon drums and staged them on site for transport and disposal.

A Contractor was called to clean-up the release and overpack the damaged product. Two drums of waste were generate for disposal; one drum of overpacked product, and one drum of neutralized rags an oil dry. The release had impacted the wooden dock floor and the asphalt beneath the trailer. No storm-drains, waterways, or soil were affected by the spill.

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Material was shipped as a non-regulated shipment of petroleum distillates. Once received the material was analyzed by our lab and the flash point of the material was determined to be 138F. The material was determined to be a hazardous waste UN 1268 Petroleum Distillates with a waste code of D001 for ignitibility. The material did ship on a hazardous waste manifest (MT# 0206124145JJK). To rectify the situation, we updated the shipping description and waste codes on the hazardous waste manifest. We relabeled the drums with hazardous waste labels and are managing the waste as hazardous.

  • Incident Date: 2024-02-09
  • City: KEARNY
  • State: NJ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On February 9, 2024, one (1) 330-gallon tote of NA1993 was punctured in transit due to no dunnage and released approximately three (3) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. FCE personnel secured the damaged tote and proceeded to transfer the NA1993 to one (1) new 330-gallon poly tote that was fitted with the appropriate labels for further shipment and processing. Crews deployed granular absorbents to the released product in the trailer and swept them in with hand tools. The one (1) empty and damaged tote was cut up with hand tools. Two (2) 55-gallon poly drums of spent absorbents, PPE, the cut-up tote, and any cleanup debris were generated as waste and staged in the terminal's waste holding room.

  • Incident Date: 2024-02-08
  • City: W SACRAMENTO
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On February 8, 2024, one (1) 5-gallon pail of UN1263 was damaged due to a load shift and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Patriot Environmental Services (PES) to remediate the impacted site. Crews deployed granular absorbents to the impacted area and worked them in with hand tools. Cleaners and absorbent pads were utilized to remove any residual product. The damaged pail, all UN1263 impacted materials, and spent absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal

item.title: Report X-2024021025
item.description:
Report X-2024021025

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-21T15:11:40+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-02-09
  • City: NEWARK
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: 1. X-2024021025 SequenceEvent: Package was located inside the trailer and smoke was coming from it I was called to retrieve the package and inspected, package was wet and when inspected it was found that the bottle was leaking from the bottom. DescribePack: bottle was cracked at the bottom. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: PPE was brought to contain the package in a hazmat bag and a tote after I cleaned the area and took another package that was leaked on or damage. 2. X-2024021114 SequenceEvent: Three of twenty identical HazMat packages were reported leaking when being unloaded at station. Of the seventeen that were assessed and determined to be unaffected and sent OFD, two more developed leaks in transit, affecting in all ten packages. These packages were transferred from the van they were on to be brought back to station for processing, along with the other seven, refused by recipient due to exposure to the leakage incident. DescribePack: Internal bottle cracked at edge of base. Crack was visually about a half inch in length, though it was only leaking from a section of the crack. DurationRel: 3 and MitigateEffect: Affected packages were removed from original van and returned to station. Unknown what other packages were aboard van that continued on its route. 3. X-2024021226 SequenceEvent: Package was inside the trailer wet and was called for an inspection and was found that one of the bottles was leaking from the bottom as it was cracked. DescribePack: Small crack at the bottom of the bottle. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Package was put into a hazmat bag and a tote and then taken into the hazmat area as well as the area where the leak happened was cleaned up.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package arrived at Hazmat location with signs of external damages. The package was inspected, and signs of internal leakage was found. Two of the contents leaked out. One was found without a cap and the other with a very loose cap. The remaining contents were placed in a salvage drum awaiting disposition. DescribePack: The package failure came about due to a missing cap from one bottle and a loose cap from another. One of the bottles leaked out in its entirety and the other bottle leaked out approximately 1/16 of its content. No holes or punctures were found on either of the bottles that leaked. DurationRel: 12 and MitigateEffect: All contents were immediately inspected, caps were replaced and tightened and placed in a lined salvage drum to prevent any further leakage or damages.

  • Description: The KAG Energy, LLC driver was delivering gasoline into the customer's storage tank. During the course of the delivery, a vehicle drove through the coned off delivery area and struck the hose adaptor. Lone Star Environmental responded to the scene and handled the remediation.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-26T15:11:07+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-22
  • City: ELK MOUNTAIN
  • State: WY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: AIRGAS SPECIALTY PRODUCTS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: The accident is still under investigation to determine the cause. What we know is the vehicle veered to the right leaving the interstate and rolling multiple times. Due to the rollover, a 2 inch pipe on the back end of the tank was broken off causing the loss of ammonia. Carbon Count FD, WY State Police and EMT's responded to the scene. I80 was closed for an estimated 5 hours, favorable wind direction allowed the interstate to reopen. We dispatched our local plant manager to the scene to help determine the severity of the leak. Once we received information back, it was determined to tarp and cover the release to help contain the fugitive vapors near the truck. Our Field Service team was activated and sent to the site to remove the remaining liquid ammonia from the truck to allow for a safe recovery of the vehicle by the tow company.

The jerrican that was leaking (Rapicide PA Part A) had a loose cap. The remaining three jerricans are still in good condition. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Manager called hazmat to came clean up the spill. The package was carefully placed in a hazard bag and the spill was clean up using adsorbents. Hazmat made sure area was safe to work in after clean up.

item.title: Report X-2024020629
item.description:
Report X-2024020629

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-23T18:13:34+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-25
  • City: EAU CLAIRE
  • State: WI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: X-2024020629, X-2024020630: SequenceEvent: improperly loaded Hazmat packages, they appeared to be stacked on top of each other, I was the one who opened the trailer because are switcher stated that the trailer had a funny smell to it. After opening the trailer, I mediately could see the damaged hazmat's actively leaking, I had are switcher pull the trailer out into the yard to air out, and after about 30 minutes I had him put the trailer back on the door, I then put on my PPE and used PH balancing powder to cover the effected spill area, after that I swept the powder up and let the trailer air out for another 30 minutes, after that I gave the go ahead to unload the trailer. DescribePack: improperly loaded Hazmat packages, they appeared to be stacked on top of each other, which caused them to fall over and start spilling due to the vented caps. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: As soon as it was safe to do so I put the hazmat's upright and brought them over to are Hazmat cage.

  • Description: It was reported that approximately 10-15 gallons of battery acid released due to battery housing fault. The release impacted a 6’ X 2’ area on the asphalt underneath the trailer and trailer floor. No storm drains or waterways were reported to be impacted by the release. EnviroServe arrived on-site and neutralized the acid with a caustic material then deployed absorbents to solidify the release. The contractor collected and containerized the impacted batteries into 3-95-gallon poly drums and all clean-up debris into 1-55-gallon poly drums. The damaged batteries that were overpacked into 3–95-gallon poly DFs were secured inside the trailer for transit. EnviroServe departed the site with the 1–55-gallon poly drum and staged the waste at their office pending disposal.

  • Description: Transport was headed West on CR1077, when the vehicle failed to negotiate the curve that curved back South. Driver stated he looked away from the roadway to check on an empty water bottle, when his steer tire went over the shoulder. The driver decided not to correct the transport, striking trees and caution chevrons, overturning the transport and splitting the trailer in half on impact. The trailer released the entire load 154 barrels. Safety was immediately dispatched from Coffeyville Resources to start clean up and remediation. The Kansas Highway Patrol was dispatched at the time of the incident, the road was diverted while the transport and trailer was towed. Clean up began on 01/21 but was delayed due to weather conditions (rain and ice). The soil has been dug up and transported to a landfill. The Coffeyville Resources Pipeline group hauled Vac trucks of the water used to keep the soil from continuing to be contaminated to the Coffeyville Refinery. The clean up was completed on 2/16.

item.title: Report I-2023120020
item.description:
Report I-2023120020

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-24T00:32:25+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-11-05
  • City: SAINT PAUL
  • State: MN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: SOO LINE RAILROAD COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: At 13:15 on 11/05/2023 a 500 Line Railroad (DBA CPKC) Hazardous Materials Officer became aware that UTLX 220854 was leaking from its protective housing at the CPKC St. Paul, MN rail yard. A railroad qualified response contractor was mobilized to investigate. Upon arrival, responders identified that the release was emanating from the threads on the nipple, where the liquid valve connects to the pressure plate. Responders could not tighten the valve because the threads were cross threaded. Because of this, absorbents were placed in the protective housing, around the leak to catch additional product and replaced daily. The shipper was notified, and subsequently mobilized a Mobile Repair Unit (MRU) to repair the car. The MRU removed the Nitrogen pad (5Ibs) that had been applied to the car at the time of shipping, which stopped the leak. However, the MRU could not remove the liquid valve to repair the connection. Because of this, the Shipper applied for an OTMA to move the car to home shop. Both CPKC and UP Railroads would not agree to this move, so the car was transferred and cleaned an purged in St. Paul. Once this was done, CPKC and UP Railroads agreed to move the car under an OTMA-1 to home shop for repairs. File Note: Item 19-the quantity released was estimated based on the best information available at the time of filing. This shipment was offered as a 'bulk' shipment, aka one car load, therefore the exact amount offered in this package is not known to the carrier. This carrier does not have access to mass balance data which can exactly quantify this value.

  • City: ROBERSONVILLE

  • Carrier/Reporter: ASSOCIATED PETROLEUM CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Our vehicle was traveling south on 1-95. The Town of Hope Mills, NC had attempted an arrest that led to a chase where the assailant fled to 1-95. The police continued the chase on 1-95 into a construction zone, the assailant attempted to pass our vehicle on the right where he was blocked with concrete barricades, and wedged his vehicle between our truck and the concrete barricades, causing him and our driver to crash. Our vehicle hit the concrete barricade on the right and the tank rolled over the concrete median, which gouged a small hole in two places on the tank, causing approx 1,500 gallons to spill on the roadway and soil adjacent to the road. The Fayetteville, NC hazmat team secured the area, plugged the holes, and controlled the pump out of the cargo tank, and allowed us to place absorbent booms to control the migration of the gasoline. No photos are available for the pump out and original damage due to the HazMat team keeping everyone away from the tanker until it was pumped out. The product was leaking approximately 7-8 hours until they could get the holes stopped up. We have hired a geologist to assist with supervising the follow up cleanup and removal of contaminated soil. That work has not begun at the time of this report.

item.title: Report I-2023110061
item.description:
Report I-2023110061

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-24T00:32:25+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-10-09
  • City: CHATTANOOGA
  • State: TN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: GREATWIDE AMERICAN TRANS-FREIGHT, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: The driver departed from the shipper and was making a left hand turn when the trailer and then the tractor over-turned onto it's passenger side. The Chattanooga Fire Department responded and Marion Environmental, Inc. (MEI) was contracted, by Greatwide, to perform cleanup and environmental remediation. During the incident, one tote containing organic peroxide solution was crushed, causing material to spill from multiple pinch points in the plastic tote. A 2nd tote spilled approximately 150 gallons from a broken lid on the fill port. Approx 270 gallons total of material spilled into the trailer, onto 100 feet of roadway, and into a storm water drain. The drain flows to Moccasin Bend Water Treatment Facility (MBWTF). No organic peroxide solution entered a natural waterway or soil. All spilled material was contained in the trailer, on the roadway, and the storm water drain. After coordinating with MBWTF personnel, the fire department flushed the drain and pushed all spilled material into the MBWTF for treatment. Sand was placed on the roadway and around the doors of the trailer to contain the spill. MEI personnel pumped the contents from all 13 of the original totes and transferred the product into 15 new totes. The shipper transported the empty totes and new totes containing product back to their facility. MEI cleaned the interior of the trailer and roadway.

item.title: Report I-2023110073
item.description:
Report I-2023110073

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-23T00:33:07+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-10-14
  • City: BROWNSVILLE
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: COASTAL TRANSPORT CO., INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: The cargo tank motor vehicle was loaded with 9700 gallons of gasoline. The driver attempted to make a 90 degree turn to the left from one roadway to another at an intersection. The vehicle's speed was too fast for conditions. The liquid load surged to the passenger side of the vehicle. The sudden weight shift to the right side caused the unit to roll over onto its right (passenger) side. The vehicle came to rest partially on the pavement and the grassy shoulder on the right side of the roadway. The driver exited from the tractor cab by crawling through the windshield frame opening. As the vehicle was lying on its right side, the liquid level rose above the manhole/venting fixtures. Gasoline began seeping through the venting fixture. The local fire department and HM response personnel placed absorbent materials around the unit. HM response personnel performed a "cold tap" drilling procedure on the side of the semi-trailer. A suction hose and pump was used to transfer product from the overturned unit into a recovery cargo tank motor vehicle. After off loading was completed, product measurements revealed approximately 450 gallons of gasoline had leaked through the venting fixture. The leaked product found its way to the ground surface alongside the pavement. Lone Star HazMat response is handing the removal and replacement of any contaminated earth alongside of the pavement.

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Vehicle was traveling south on NC-9. Vehicle traveled off rightside of the roadway, collided with a ditch and overturned to the left, coming to rest in the roadway on its left side. The driver immediately called and reported the incident to 911. The driver then notified his safety officer, which immediately dispatched a remediation crew. The dome lid of the #2 compartment dripped diesel fuel for approximately 5 hours (approximately 25 LGA which was contained with spill pads and boom). Advance Environmental Options, Inc mitigated the release.

item.title: Report I-2023120010
item.description:
Report I-2023120010

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-23T00:33:07+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-10-30
  • City: KANSAS CITY
  • State: MO
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: THE KANSAS CITY SOUTHERN RAILWAY COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: At 2210 on 10/30/2023 CPKC personnel reported seeing an exhaust coming out of the top of a loaded hazmat car, TILX 112325, at the CPKC Knoche yard in Kansas City, MO. The CPKC Hazmat Department mobilized, along with a response contractor, to investigate and mitigate the release. Upon assessment, responders found that the pressure relief device (PRD) had actuated releasing approximately 0.5 gallons of commodity. The tank car was then moved with reacher cars to an isolation track where it was decontaminated to a 7 pH. The package was inspected and not found to be overloaded or over pressured. CPKC Hazmat concluded that the PRD might be defective. The shipper was contacted and advised that the tank car is currently a FRA non-specification package and required that the PRD be tested and proved to be functioning, or replaced by a qualified MRU. Shipper was also made aware that the car would need a FRA OTMA before it could be moved. As of the date of this filing, the shipper and car owner are working to verify proper PRD operation before the car will be released back into rail transportation. File Note: Item 19-the quantity released was estimated based on the best information available at the time of filing. This shipment was offered as a 'bulk' shipment, aka one car load, therefore the exact amount offered in this package is not known to the carrier. This carrier does not have access to mass balance data which can exactly quantify this value.
